statement:
We use the curved from the Laplace-transformed functions to the
corresponding initial functions.\
If $$f(t,x) \;\,\curvearrowleft\;\, F(s,x),$$ then one can differentiate
both functions with respect to the parametre $x$: $$\begin{aligned}
f'_x(t,x)  \;\,\curvearrowleft\;\, F'_x(s,x)\end{aligned}$$ (1) may be
written also as $$\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{L}\{\frac{\partial}{\partial x}f(t,x)}\}
\;=\; \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\mathcal{L}\{f(t,x)\}.\end{aligned}$$

[*Proof.*]{} We differentiate partially both sides of the defining
equation $$F(s,x) \;:= \int_0^\infty e^{-st}f(t,x)\,dt,$$ on the right
hand side , getting $$\begin{aligned}
F'_x(s,x) \;=\; \int_0^\infty e^{-st}f'_x(t,x)\,dx,\end{aligned}$$ which
means same as (1). Q.E.D.\
**Example.** If the rule
$$\frac{s}{s^2\!-\!a^2} \;\,\curvearrowright\;\, \cosh{at}$$ is
differentiated with respect to $a$, the result is
$$\frac{2as}{(s^2\!-\!a^2)^2}\;\,\curvearrowright
\;\, t\,\sinh{at}.$$\
